photo.description: The Basilica di Santa Maria della Salute (Basilica of St Mary of Health/Salvation), commonly known simply as the Salute, is a famous church in Venice, placed scenically at a narrow finger of land which lies between the Grand Canal and the Bacino di San Marco on the lagoon, visible as one enters the Piazza San Marco from the water. (Wikipedia)

photo.title: Basilica of St Mary of Health/Salvation, Venice

photo.description: View of the Basilica from the Grand Canal. Venice, Italy. After two years of plague killed nearly a third of the population of Venice, the Venetian Senate decreed that a new church would be built. It was not to be dedicated to a mere "plague" or patron saint, but to the Virgin Mary, who for many reasons was thought to be a protector of the Republic.

photo.title: Basilica of St. Mary of Health

photo.description: Venice, Italy
photo.tags: italy venice church salute santamariadellasalute basilica basilicaofstmaryofhealth
photo.title: Santa Maria della Salute

photo.description: When in Rome, do as the Romans do; in Venice, take a nice relaxing Gondola ride! Behind our intrepid and talented gondolier is the beautiful and ornate 17th Century Basilica Santa Maria della Salute, or Church of St. Mary of Health. This Baroque masterpiece was built as an offering to St. Mary to combat the devastating Bubonic Plague (or Black Death) epidemic that ravaged Venice in 1629-30. Construction began in 1631 and the church was consecrated in 1681.
photo.tags: italy vacation europe venice venezia canal gondola basilica santa maria della salute church st mary health
photo.title: O, sole Mio! Gondola ride in Venice, Italy

photo.title: Salute

photo.description: The Basilica of St Mary of Health (Italian: Basilica di Santa Maria della Salute), commonly known simply as the Salute, is a Roman Catholic church and minor basilica located in the Dorsoduro sestiere of the Italian city of Venice. It stands on a narrow finger of land between the Grand Canal and the Bacino di San Marco making the church visible when entering the Piazza San Marco from the water. The Salute is part of the parish of the Gesuati and is the most recent of the so-called Plague-churches. In 1630 Venice experienced an unusually devastating outbreak of the plague. As a votive offering for the city's deliverance from the pestilence, the Republic of Venice vowed to build and dedicate a church to Our Lady of Health (or of Deliverance, Italian: Salute). The church was designed in the then fashionable baroque style by Baldassare Longhena, who studied under the architect Vincenzo Scamozzi. Construction began in 1631. Most of the objects of art housed in the church bear references to the Black Death.

photo.description: The Basilica di Santa Maria della Salute (Basilica of St Mary of Health/Salvation), commonly known simply as the Salute, is one of the largest churches of Venice and has the status of a minor basilica. It stands at the junction between the Grand Canal and the Bacino di San Marco on the lagoon.

photo.description: Viewed from the gondola. The Basilica of St Mary of Health/Salvation was built after the plague killed almost 2/3 of the Venetian population in the summer of 1629. In part, a monument to those who had died.

photo.title: Basilica di Santa Maria della Salute

photo.description: "The Basilica di Santa Maria della Salute (Basilica of St Mary of Health/Salvation), commonly known simply as the Salute, is a famous church in Venice, placed scenically at a narrow finger of land which lies between the Grand Canal and the Bacino di San Marco on the lagoon, visible as one enters the Piazza San Marco from the water. While it has the status of a minor basilica, its decorative and distinctive profile and location make it among the most photographed churches in Italy." Source: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Maria_della_Salute "Santa Maria della Salute (o Chiesa della Salute o semplicemente La Salute) è una basilica di Venezia eretta vicino alla Punta della Dogana, da dove risalta nel panorama del Bacino di San Marco e del Canal Grande. Progettata da Baldassarre Longhena con attenzione ai modelli del Palladio, è una delle migliori espressioni dell’architettura barocca veneziana. La sua costruzione rappresenta un ex voto alla Madonna da parte dei veneziani per la liberazione dalla peste che tra il 1630 e il 1631 decimò la popolazione, come era avvenuto in precedenza per le chiese del Redentore e di San Rocco." Fuente: it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basilica_di_Santa_Maria_della_Salut...
photo.tags: italy church chiesa iglesia venice venecia venezia basilicadisantamariadellasalute marble detail religion religious sacred floor color colorful design diseño dibujo

photo.description: The construction of Salute was announced in 1630 in response to the Plague, and completed in 1681. It was built here for easy processional access and to form an arc with San Giorgio, San Marco and Il Redentore. Venice.

photo.title: Venezia, Basilica di Santa Maria della Salute e Torre dell'Orologio

photo.description: The Basilica of St Mary of Health (Italian: Basilica di Santa Maria della Salute), commonly known simply as the Salute, is a Roman Catholic church and minor basilica located in the Dorsoduro sestiere of the Italian city of Venice. It stands on a narrow finger of land between the Grand Canal and the Bacino di San Marco making the church visible when entering the Piazza San Marco from the water. The Salute is part of the parish of the Gesuati and is the most recent of the so-called Plague-churches. In 1630 Venice experienced an unusually devastating outbreak of the plague. As a votive offering for the city's deliverance from the pestilence, the Republic of Venice vowed to build and dedicate a church to Our Lady of Health (or of Deliverance, Italian: Salute). The church was designed in the then fashionable Palladian style by Baldassare Longhena, a pupil of the Venetian architect Andrea Palladio, and construction began in 1631. Most of the objects of art housed in the church bear references to the Black Death. The dome of the Salute was an important addition to the Venice skyline and soon became emblematic of the city, inspiring artists like Canaletto, J. M. W. Turner, John Singer Sargent and Francesco Guardi. The Salute is a vast, octagonal building with two domes and a pair of picturesque bell-towers at the back. Built on a platform made of 100,000 wooden piles, it is constructed of Istrian stone and marmorino (brick covered with marble dust). At the apex of the pediment stands a statue of the Virgin Mary who presides over the church which was erected in her honour. The façade is decorated with figures of Saint George, Saint Theodore, the Evangelists, the Prophets, Judith with the head of Holofernes.
photo.tags: venecia italy italia grand canal gondola sanmarco gondolero gondolier vaporetto campanile santamariadellasalute
photo.title: Santa Maria della Salute
